item.title: Experimental Linguistics with Ibex Farm
item.description: Ibex Farm 🐐 is an online resource that allows you to create psycholinguistic experiments that you can then send to participants. Ibex Farm runs using JavaScript and HTML 💻. The cool thing about it is that it is highly customizable and it allows you to measure reaction times (RTs) and to randomize items, among other things. You can check out the Ibex Farm website here and its documentation here. I have used Ibex Farm to design picture-matching tasks where participants heard sentences and had to choose the picture that best matched each sentence.

item.title: The Languages of Frida Kahlo
item.description: This project compares the English and Spanish subtitles from the movie Frida (2002) 🎥. Subtitle files were imported into R and examined using several natural language processing (NLP) tools and techniques, such as: Tokenization Bigrams N-gram analysis Sentiment analysis Results were also plotted for a better interpretation 📊📈. Some of the packages used include: tidyverse tidytext stringi igraph ggraph syuzhet

item.title: Heritage Language Writing
item.description: Heritage speakers are a specific type of bilingual speakers who grew up exposed to a home language different from the one spoken by majority in society. When heritage speakers start school, they learn the majority language which, in most cases, ends up being their dominant language 🗣️. item.title: Little Red Riding Hood Corpus
item.description: This corpus comprises several texts which are transcriptions of the Little Red Riding Hood fairy tale as told by different bilingual speakers. All narratives were produced in Spanish and were elicited using a children’s book (containing only images, not text) 📖. Bilingual speakers were either born in the United States or in a country in Latin America (e.g., Mexico, Venezuela…), and they were fluent in both English and Spanish. Transcriptions were included in a single Word document.

item.title: Structural Priming
item.description: Structural priming is the tendency to repeat or more easily process a syntactic structure that a speaker has been recently exposed to. Linguistic experiments that use structural priming try to understand how language is represented in the mind 🧠. This project used a structural priming paradigm to examine how different speakers (i.e., native speakers, second language speakers, and heritage speakers) process ditransitive constructions in Spanish. The experiment consisted of a pre-test, treatment, and post-test.
